Text: (Now, then.)
(There aren't that many guards inside.)
(But that doesn't mean they're slacking...)

(They're setting magic detecting traps all over
the place.)

(They only have guards stationed where the building
design makes it hard to set traps.)

(And together with the traps, the Paladins on guard
are constantly monitoring the control of magic.)

(So, if any of them faint or lose magical control for
some reason, then everyone will know something's up.)

(I get the impression this place is much more
tightly guarded than the Lindwurm Cathedral.)

(Well, I know the Church has different factions,
and Orum's is different from the one in Lindwurm,
so I guess they all have their own ways.)

(I'll just have to sneak in through the gaps in the
trap network.)

(If fate is truly cruel, the important intel will be
hidden in the hardest place to reach.)

(This is a guest reception room, I suppose...
It really shows off the Church's money.)

(They'd never hide anything important in a public
place like this. But...)
(There we are. A hidden door in the fireplace.)

(How convenient! The whole fireplace spins open.
No worry about soot getting on your clothes.
What a cleverly designed setup.)

(This relief showing an ancient miracle is a very
subtle magical lock that opens when you run
magic through a preset pattern.)

(I saw the same thing at the Lindwurm Cathedral.
Good thing I came prepared.)

(The kind of magic seals used to seal up ritual rooms
are usually sacred ancient relics of the Church.)

(Their opening methods are sacred mysteries passed on
to acolytes along with the Holy Teachings.)

(Calling those secrets an ancient ritual is a good
way to preserve them, actually. It's a pretty
clever setup.)

(But since it's based on magical flow, opening one is
just a matter of studying the teachings to figure out
the proper magical manipulation.)

(Sadly, the magic itself doesn't care about little
things like right or wrong, good or bad.)

(I just need to manipulate the cylinders inside
the lock with magic while avoiding detection by
the traps.)

(The tablet that Beta and Epsilon brought back holds
ciphers that correspond to Church scripture.)

(So, I can guess the scripture from this relief
sculpture, then use the ciphers I've memorized
to find the correct key.)

(Now, to just move the cylinders like the
relief shows...)

(And then I should find a secret passage. I wonder
if Epsilon could have opened it faster.)

(There's a good chance they've hidden a clever little
trap here...)

(...Since the stone used in the tablet constantly
emits magic energy as a theft deterrent. The
magic detectors would easily pick up
on any changes.)

(The Templars must already know that the tablet is
gone from the Holy State.)

(Still, I'll be taking a look around. Let's see what
we have here!)

(Perfumed oil... It's masking the smell of something.
What is that? It's blood! And fairly old, too.)

(Ash and charcoal from the fireplace also help to
hide the smell, I see.)
(But, still...)

(I can't discover anything without having a look
around. This is such an odd, unpleasant space.)

(But above all, it's connected to the reception
room.)

(Some big shot with Church connections could bring
in prisoners or hostages...)

(Or maybe even invite a rival to an "audience" at
the cathedral, then drag them off for
a little "chat".)

(Whatever the case may be, this is one scary
cathedral.)
Right, no magic-detecting traps in here, of course.
But I can't be sure no one sensed the lock opening.
I'd better just search and get out of here—
